title: 109_s4100
content: The "Secure Travel and Counterterrorism Partnership Act" aims to expand the visa waiver program to provide visa-free travel privileges to allies in the war on terrorism. This expansion is intended to enhance counterterrorism cooperation, promote tourism and business opportunities, and strengthen bilateral relationships. The Secure Travel and Counterterrorism Partnership Act will amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to establish a pilot program allowing up to 5 foreign countries not designated as program countries to participate in the visa waiver program. Eligibility for participation is based on certain criteria. The Secure Travel and Counterterrorism Partnership Act will establish a pilot program allowing up to 5 foreign countries to participate in the visa waiver program if certain criteria are met, including not compromising US security interests, meeting requirements for program designation, and developing a strategic plan within 3 years. The Secure Travel and Counterterrorism Partnership Act will establish a pilot program for up to 5 foreign countries to join the visa waiver program if they meet security and integrity requirements for travel documents, cooperate on counterterrorism initiatives, and have agreements with the US government. The Secure Travel and Counterterrorism Partnership Act establishes a pilot program for up to 5 foreign countries to join the visa waiver program by agreeing to advance US security interests through additional counterterrorism cooperation and information sharing measures as requested by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The selection of countries may be based on visa refusal rates for nonimmigrant visitor visas. The Secretary of Homeland Security may consider visa overstay rates when deciding whether a country can participate in the program under the Secure Travel and Counterterrorism Partnership Act. The decision cannot be based solely on the overstay rate unless it is deemed a security concern to the United States. The Secure Travel and Counterterrorism Partnership Act allows foreign countries to participate in the program for an initial 3-year term, with a possible 2-year extension if significant progress is shown. The Secure Travel and Counterterrorism Partnership Act allows foreign countries to participate in the program for an initial 3-year term, with a possible 2-year extension if significant progress is shown. Countries must meet requirements for designation, submit a plan, and not compromise US security or law enforcement interests to continue participation. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to terminate a country's participation. The Secretary of Homeland Security can terminate a country's participation in the program if they are not compliant with the requirements or fail to show progress towards meeting them. The Secretary of Homeland Security, with input from the Secretary of State, will offer technical guidance to program countries to help them meet the necessary requirements. Additionally, an annual report on the program's implementation must be submitted to Congress, with a final assessment due within 30 days of a country's participation. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, will submit a final assessment to Congress after a foreign country's participation in the program ends. This assessment will include recommendations for allowing more countries to join the program. SEC. 4. CALCULATION OF THE RATES OF VISA OVERSTAYS. The Secretary of Homeland Security will develop procedures to improve calculating rates of nonimmigrants violating visa terms by staying in the US after expiration. SEC. 5. REPORTS. SEC. 5. REPORTS. The Comptroller General will review visa fees and submit a report to Congress. The Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of State will submit a report on enhancing secure travel standards for visa waiver program countries. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2007 through 2013 to carry out the Act and its amendment.
